path: ./Audit_Reports_2024/Coinfabrik/Money on Chain Security Audit IV - CoinFabrik Blog.pdf

findings.title: Misuse of the different call methods: call.value(), send() and transfer()
findings.description: The audit report highlights the misuse of different call methods, specifically call.value(), send(), and transfer(). This could lead to potential security vulnerabilities.

findings.title: Integer Rounding Errors, Overflow, Underflow, and SafeMath Functions
findings.description: The audit report highlights potential issues with integer rounding errors, overflows, underflows, and related usage of SafeMath functions.

findings.title: Old compiler version pragmas
findings.description: Using old compiler version pragmas can lead to security vulnerabilities and compatibility issues.

findings.title: Race conditions such as reentrancy attacks or front running
findings.description: Reentrancy attacks can occur when a token is able to call the MoC contracts back.

findings.title: Misuse of block timestamps
findings.description: Assuming anything other than them being strictly increasing

findings.title: Contract softlocking attacks (DoS)
findings.description: A type of Denial-of-Service attack where an attacker can cause a contract to become stuck or 'locked' in a particular state, making it unable to perform any further actions.

findings.title: Potential gas cost of functions being over the gas limit
findings.description: The gas cost of certain functions may exceed the gas limit, leading to potential issues with transaction execution.

findings.title: Missing function qualifiers and their misuse
Fallback functions with a higher gas cost than the one that a transfer or send call allows
findings.description: The fallback function has a higher gas cost than what is allowed by the transfer or send call, potentially leading to unintended behavior.

findings.title: Code and contract interaction complexity
findings.description: The audit report highlights the complexity of code and contract interactions as a potential security risk.

findings.title: Overuse of transfers in a single transaction instead of using withdrawal patterns
findings.description: Using multiple transfers in a single transaction can lead to unintended behavior and potential security risks, instead of implementing a withdrawal pattern.

findings.title: Insufficient analysis of the function input requirements
